description: From Middle English *gloom, *glom, from Old English glōm (“gloaming, twilight, darkness”), from Proto-West Germanic *glōm, from Proto-Germanic *glōmaz (“gleam, shimmer, sheen”), from Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰley- (“to gleam, shimmer, glow”). The English word is cognate with Norwegian glom (“transparent membrane”), Scots gloam (“twilight; faint light; dull gleam”).

examples: the gloom of a forest, or of midnight

entries.meaning: A depressing, despondent, or melancholic atmosphere.
Cloudiness or heaviness of mind; melancholy; aspect of sorrow; low spirits; dullness.
examples: A sullen gloom and furious disorder prevailed by fits.

entries.meaning: A drying oven used in gunpowder manufacture.

verbs.description: gloom (third-person singular simple present glooms, present participle glooming, simple past and past participle gloomed)

examples: Around all the dark forest gloomed.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To look or feel sad, sullen or despondent.
examples: Ciss was a big, dark-complexioned, pug-faced young woman who seemed to be glooming about something.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To render gloomy or dark; to obscure; to darken.
(transitive) To fill with gloom; to make sad, dismal, or sullen.
To shine or appear obscurely or imperfectly; to glimmer.
